definition: Ordering learning experiences to build logically from simpler to more complex, ensuring prerequisites precede dependent skills

positive_examples: Students must master addition before we introduce multiplication.
The task analysis revealed five prerequisite skills that need to be taught first.
Learning progressions map how understanding develops from novice to expert.
Each step builds on the previous one in a logical sequence.
negative_examples: We'll cover topics in whatever order feels interesting.
Jump straight to the advanced technique without building up to it.
The curriculum follows the textbook order without analyzing dependencies.
training_hints.disambiguation: Logical ordering based on dependencies, not arbitrary sequencing
